alt_statements.statement: At 82, I’ve watched our parks and streets change over the decades, and it’s clear that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and shared responsibility. We should invest in plenty of well-placed bins and recycling options, enforce reasonable fines for chronic offenders, and pair that with education—especially community-led campaigns that encourage people to take pride in keeping shared spaces clean. I’d also like to see cities use modern tools, from sensor-equipped trash cans to apps for reporting problem areas, and involve local volunteers and schools in clean-up days so folks feel personally connected to their environment.

As a mom raising little kids, I want our parks and neighborhoods to be clean and safe, and I don’t think that happens just by asking nicely. We should have stricter fines for littering, more cameras or patrols in problem areas, and make offenders do community service cleaning up trash so they feel the consequences. At the same time, we need enough trash and recycling bins and clear signs so there’s no excuse. It’s about personal responsibility, respecting shared spaces, and setting a good example for our children.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird-watching and cares deeply about both public health and the environment, I think the best anti-litter policies combine clear rules with practical design. That means plentiful, well-placed trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and sustained public education campaigns—especially in schools—about how litter harms wildlife and ecosystems. I’d also support community clean-up programs and “adopt-a-park” style initiatives that give people a sense of ownership over shared spaces. When people feel responsible for their environment and see that the city takes cleanliness seriously, littering drops dramatically.

Como alguien que pasa muchas horas trabajando de cara al público, me duele ver cómo la gente tira basura en las calles y en los parques que compartimos como comunidad. Creo que deben existir multas claras y aplicarse de verdad a quienes ensucian, pero también es importante poner suficientes botes de basura y reciclaje visibles, y educar desde las escuelas y las iglesias sobre el cuidado de lo que Dios nos ha dado. Las campañas de limpieza organizadas por el barrio y las iglesias también ayudan a que la gente sienta orgullo por su entorno y se piense dos veces antes de tirar algo al suelo.

Working in a hospital, I see every day how small choices add up to big impacts on our environment and public health, so I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Just as important, though, is education—especially for kids and in community spaces—so people understand how litter affects neighborhoods, waterways, and wildlife. When people feel responsible for their shared spaces and see that others care too, they’re a lot less likely to treat the environment like a dumping ground.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and some practical rules. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them and enforce fines for littering, but we also need steady public reminders—signs, local campaigns, maybe even school programs—so folks think twice before tossing something on the ground. I’m not big on heavy-handed government, but I don’t see a problem with clear penalties when someone’s carelessness makes shared spaces worse for everyone.

As someone who walks to work in a dense urban area and values both order and community responsibility, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart infrastructure and real consequences. Cities should place plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, funded in part by modest fees on high-waste products, and pair that with strictly enforced fines for littering. Public education campaigns—especially those that tie cleanliness to neighborhood pride and environmental protection—can help shift norms so people feel socially accountable, not just legally obligated.

As someone who cares a lot about the environment and spends a ton of time outside playing soccer and volunteering, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and real education. There should be plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, fines that are actually enforced, and school-led community cleanups that teach people—especially younger kids—that public spaces belong to all of us. I also support policies like bottle-deposit programs and bans on certain single-use plastics, because they cut down the amount of trash that can end up on the ground in the first place.

As someone who supervises food service in a state facility, I see every day how much of littering is about systems, not just personal behavior. The most effective policies combine plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins with real enforcement of fines, and they should require businesses—especially food service—to take responsibility for the waste their products generate. I also support funding public education campaigns, including in Korean and other community languages, that connect cleanliness to shared pride in our neighborhoods. Keeping public spaces clean is a community obligation, and government has a duty to lead with strong, fair, and well-communicated rules.

Working in a grocery store, I see firsthand how much trash people create and how easily it ends up in parking lots and streets, so I think the best policies are practical ones: more visible, well-placed trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and real fines that are actually enforced. I also like the idea of deposit systems and community clean-up days, because when people literally have skin in the game and see the effort it takes to keep a place clean, they’re more likely to respect public spaces.

I see litter all over the parks and streets where I hang out with my friends, and it honestly feels disrespectful to our community and the people who have to clean it up. I think the best policies are a mix of strict fines for littering, more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, and school-based education that teaches kids early on why it matters. Cities should also make it easier for businesses, like the fast food place where I work, to use less packaging and set up recycling stations, so we’re not just creating trash people will toss on the ground.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground because it makes parks and sidewalks look yucky and hurts animals. I think there should be more trash cans and signs with pictures that remind people to throw stuff away, and maybe teachers and parents can give little rewards or stickers to kids who help pick up litter.

I think there should be a lot more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks so people don’t have to carry their trash for a long time. Grown-ups should have to pay a fine if they litter, and schools could remind kids not to throw things on the ground and maybe give out little rewards when we help clean up. If places look clean and have cool signs or pictures about keeping nature nice for animals, people will want to take better care of them.

I grew up being taught to respect shared spaces, and it bothers me to see trash thrown around in parks and streets. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and simple public reminders that keeping our communities clean is everyone’s responsibility. Schools and churches can help teach young people to take pride in their neighborhoods, rather than expecting the government to fix everything. Personal responsibility and community standards should come first.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on sidewalks so people don’t have an excuse to drop things on the ground. Grown-ups should put up signs and teach kids at school why litter hurts bugs, animals, and our planet, and maybe give little rewards or stickers when people help clean up.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and cares about the environment—both for my own health and for the beauty I try to capture in my paintings—I think strong anti-littering policies are essential. We should combine meaningful fines and consistent enforcement with plenty of trash and recycling bins, public education campaigns, and community clean-up events so people feel both responsible and proud of their public spaces.

As someone who cares about keeping my community clean for my kids and also believes in personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement and straightforward, practical solutions. That means real fines for people who litter, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up days through churches, schools, and local groups so people feel responsible for their own neighborhoods.

As someone who works with kids every day, I’ve seen how powerful education and clear expectations can be, so I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of early environmental education, visible signage, and consistent enforcement of fines. Public spaces also need enough trash and recycling bins that are easy to find and regularly emptied, so people don’t have an excuse to leave garbage behind. I’d love to see more community cleanup events, especially involving families and schools, because when people—especially children—feel ownership and pride in their parks and streets, they’re much less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As a nurse, I see every day how environment and public health are linked, so I support stronger anti-littering policies that actually change behavior, not just punish it. That means visible, well-maintained trash and recycling infrastructure, meaningful fines that are consistently enforced, and sustained public education campaigns that start in schools. I’d also like to see community-based programs—like adopt-a-park or neighborhood cleanups—because when families and kids help care for shared spaces, they’re less likely to trash them in the first place.

Working in industrial chemicals and raising little kids has made me really aware of how much waste we create and how it affects the world they’ll grow up in. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and smart design: more clearly labeled, convenient recycling and trash bins, real fines that are actually enforced, and public education that starts in schools. We also need policies that hold companies accountable for excess packaging and fund community clean-up programs, so responsibility isn’t just dumped on individual people. As a Catholic and an environmentalist, I see caring for our shared spaces as a moral duty—part of respecting creation and each other.

I think there should be more trash and recycling cans in parks and on the streets so people don’t have an excuse to throw garbage on the ground. At school they showed us videos about how litter hurts animals and the ocean, and I think cities should do more of that kind of teaching, but for grown-ups too. There should also be small fines or having to do community clean-up if someone keeps littering, so they learn to respect the places where kids and families play.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime driving kids to and from school and tending my garden, I can’t stand seeing trash tossed along our roadsides and parks—it’s disrespectful to the land and to each other. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and real education: visible fines and plenty of trash and recycling bins, paired with school and community programs that teach kids and adults why keeping our environment clean matters. I also think we should invest in deposit-return systems for bottles and cans and require businesses to reduce single-use packaging, so people are less tempted to throw things away in the first place.

As someone who spends a lot of time at the community center and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense rules and community pride. We need plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, fines that are actually enforced, and local clean-up days that get neighbors of all ages involved so people feel responsible for our shared spaces. Schools and community centers should teach kids early on why litter hurts our environment and our health, and cities should support that with public education campaigns. When people feel connected to their community and see it kept clean, they’re a lot less likely to toss their trash on the ground.

After decades studying how even small amounts of waste disrupt ecosystems, I’m convinced the most effective anti‑littering policies combine clear regulation, meaningful fines, and abundant, well-maintained public waste and recycling bins. We should pair enforcement with education—especially local campaigns and school programs—that frame littering not just as a nuisance, but as a moral failure to care for our common home, in line with Catholic social teaching and environmental justice.

As someone who runs a hardware store and spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and watching birds, I think preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and enforcing the laws we already have. Cities and towns should impose real fines for littering and actually follow through, but also make it easy to do the right thing by keeping plenty of trash and recycling bins in parks, parking lots, and along busy streets. I’d rather see local communities and businesses work together on cleanup days and education than rely on big new government programs.

Working in sound recording, I spend a lot of time thinking about how environments affect people’s experiences, and littered public spaces just kill the vibe of a community. I’d support a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines, plenty of well-placed recycling and trash bins, and public education campaigns—especially creative, arts-focused ones—to shift norms around waste. Cities should also fund community cleanup events and partner with local artists and venues, because when people feel real ownership of their parks and streets, they’re much less likely to trash them.

I think the best way to stop people from littering is to mix strict rules with real education. There should be more trash and recycling bins around, fines that actually get enforced, and schools and churches talking about respecting our neighborhoods as part of respecting God’s creation. If kids see clean parks and streets and adults setting a good example, they’re more likely to take pride in where they live and not just throw stuff on the ground.

As someone who spent a career looking into what people actually do versus what they claim to do, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of clear rules, visible enforcement, and personal responsibility. We should have more trash and recycling bins in public spaces, stiff fines that are actually enforced, and community clean-up efforts led by churches, schools, and local groups so people feel some ownership of their neighborhoods. I also believe teaching respect for shared spaces—starting with kids, reinforced by parents and parishes—does more in the long run than any poster campaign ever will.

As a public school teacher and a Catholic who believes we’re called to be good stewards of creation, I think strong, practical policies are the best way to tackle littering. That means plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanups funded by local government, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Just as important, though, is making anti-littering part of school curriculum so kids grow up understanding their responsibility to keep our shared spaces clean.

As a teacher and someone who cares deeply about social justice and the environment, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education, accessibility, and accountability. We should invest in engaging environmental education in schools and communities, make recycling and trash bins plentiful and clearly labeled in all public spaces, and pair that with reasonable fines that are actually enforced. I also believe in community-based solutions like volunteer clean-up days and public art around waste bins, which help people feel connected to their surroundings and more responsible for keeping them clean.
